content:
The Numbers

Wyre Borough Council's spending data reveals £678 million in external payments across 51,092 transactions with just 1,558 unique suppliers spanning April 2017 to March 2026 — nine years of financial data.

As a district council with an annual budget of approximately £12 million, Wyre covers the Fylde coast area including Fleetwood, Thornton-Cleveleys, and Garstang. The council handles housing, planning, waste collection, and leisure services, while Lancashire County Council provides education, social care, and highways.

The Concentration Problem

Wyre has the most concentrated supplier base in Lancashire — and it is not even close. The HHI stands at 2,796.8, classified as HIGH concentration. For comparison, the next highest district council (Chorley) has an HHI of 2,131, and most Lancashire councils sit below 500.

The reason is stark: Lancashire County Council receives 48% of all Wyre's recorded spending. Nearly half of every pound Wyre processes goes to the county council — primarily waste disposal levies, but potentially also shared service arrangements and other inter-authority payments.

With only 1,558 suppliers for £678 million in spending, Wyre has the narrowest supplier base of any council on the platform. This is less than a third of the suppliers used by neighbouring West Lancashire (4,614) despite similar spending volumes.

Red Flags in the Data

Wyre's automated DOGE analysis returned a fraud triangle score of 63.4 out of 100. The key findings:

  • HHI of 2,796.8 — HIGH concentration, with Lancashire CC receiving 48% of all spend
  • Benford's Law deviation of 7.6% — a high max digit deviation that exceeds the 5% warning threshold
  • Only 1,558 suppliers for £678 million — an extremely narrow supplier base suggesting limited competitive procurement

The Benford's Law result, combined with the extreme supplier concentration, paints a picture of a council where competitive procurement may be limited. When half of spending goes to a single counterparty and the supplier pool is the smallest in Lancashire, the scope for achieving value for money through competition is inherently constrained.

Political Context

Wyre Borough Council is controlled by the Conservatives. The borough is one of Lancashire's more affluent areas, with lower deprivation than East Lancashire councils, which is reflected in relatively lower demand for social services at the district level.

Data Quality

Nine years of spending data provides a strong baseline for analysis. However, the extreme dominance of Lancashire CC payments in the dataset makes it difficult to assess the council's own procurement decisions — the majority of recorded spending is inter-authority transfers rather than discretionary commercial procurement.

Explore the full dataset on our Spending page, or see our DOGE Investigation for deeper analysis.
